1st BioCatalogue Strategy Advisory Board meeting

Date: 20th March 2009

Location: University of Manchester

Attending: Carole Goble, Jiten Bhagat, Steve Pettifer, Franck Tanoh, Rodrigo Lopez, Thomas Laurent, Eric Nzuobontane, Chris Rawlings, Anil Wipat, Jo Dicks, Steve Kemp, Antoine H.C. van Kampen, Holger Lausen, Terry Payne

Apologies: Robert Stevens, Mark Wilkinson, Robert Gill, Katy Wolstencroft

Agenda

  • Presentation of the BioCatalogue project (Carole Goble)
  • Presentation of the Seekda project (Holger Lausen)
  • Demonstration of the BioCatalogue private release (Jiten Bhagat, Eric Nzuobontane)
  • Discussion about current state of the project as well as about its future development

1. Presentation of the BioCatalogue project

BioCatalogue presentation

2. Presentation of the Seekda project

Seekda presentation

3. Demonstration of the BioCatalogue private release

BioCatalogue private release

4. Discussion

The Project

  • SAB asked “What is the main criteria from the BBSRC for evaluation of this program ?”

Answer: Does anybody use it? How much content? Is it crucial to the community? Significant coverage of the field.

Search

  • Search terms matched to ontologies, allowing for richer searches.
  • Thesaurus based search term expansion and presentation of results
  • BioCatalogue, searchable by Google and EBI search engine.
  • BioCatalogue to use standard tools for search expansion.
  • Have a look at the clustering engine carrot2 to enhance the search results returned by SOLR.
  • Have a look at COHSE to get broader terms and narrower terms.

Browsing

  • Facetted browsing: classification of services based on domain e.g. proteomic, genomic, metabolomic…etc.
  • Sourcing from ontology; myGrid ontology may not be enough to annotate all services. We need to source from other ontology as well.

Registration

  • At registration point ask users/providers to accept terms/conditions; we need advice on that issue e.g. from the business school here in Manchester. We should also ask if the submitter is the provider/owner of the service (how do we do service ownership management ?).
  • Feedback loop to users and service providers need to be more explicit.
  • We should ask if submitter of a Web Service is also the owner and ask for the type of notifications wanted.

Annotation

  • Possibility to use other ontology as well
  • What a provider gets from providing more metadata.
  • Make sure we don’t mislead people about services having a lot of metadata but with a bad quality service.

Quality of service

  • Need to separate subjective rating from objective rating. We should be careful with rating not to offend providers.
  • Speed of a service difficult to measure and very subjective.
  • Feedback to provider is an important aspect of the monitoring piece.
  • “Did it do what I want it to do?”
  • “Did it do what it said it would do?”
  • We need to separate out machine vs human AND subjective vs objective measurements

Social networking

  • We need to be careful not to appear to support any comment post to the BioCatalogue (write disclaimer).
  • Provide service providers clear paths and opportunities to respond to negative comments.
  • Suggestion: Multiple comment threads (using DISQUS) to be able to separate general comments from technical issues with a Web Service.
  • We probably shouldn’t allow anonymous comments.
  • Provide a “did you find this comment useful”.
  • Provide a “did you find Web Service you were looking for” for both anonymous and registered users.

Testing

  • Test script is an example of how to run a service
  • Tests are a valuable information for users but also an important feedback for service providers (test that their service is working and reachable by the outside world)

Metrics

  • How many times a Web Service has been seen/visited
  • We could check how e-commerce websites handles ranking (in literature, with business school…)

Launch strategy

  • BioCuration/BioIT - silent launch (open up the beta site)
  • ISMB/ECCB in July, the real launch target. A poster has already been submitted and a demo will be subitted as well (Taverna integration will be ready by then).
  • We can investigate using Google ads but very VERY expensive.
  • Mailing lists to advertise the launch on ?
  • Press releases: talk to journal/publisher about BioCatalogue
  • Newsletters BBSRC
  • Students and teaching – Anil’s help
  • EU networks
  • Sponsorship of activities

Long term recognition of BioCatalogue

  • BioCatalogue, the place where publishers such as NAR point their submitters to register web services.
  • BioCatalogue the number one web service registry for life science

Term of reference SAB

  • A quarterly small report to send to the SAB team.
  • Meeting once a year.
  • Create a SAB mailing list for contact

Action

  • Franck, submit ISMB demo abstract by 20th April
  • Carole to talk at the BioIT meeting about our policy
  • All, Holger invitation for a meeting between the BioCatalogue team and service finder team
  • Rodrigo: DDBJ, NCBI – ownership and diplomacy
  • Franck: Sourcing from ontology to be added to the task list
  • Jits: Create a mailing list for the SAB team
